module.title: Electronic Devices & Circuits
module.description: Master electronic devices including diodes, transistors, and operational amplifiers for RRB exam preparation

Analyze transistor configurations and amplifier circuits
Design and analyze operational amplifier circuits
Solve practical circuit problems for RRB examinations

diodes.title: Semiconductor Diodes
objectives: Understand PN junction formation and characteristics
Analyze diode IV curves and parameters
Master special purpose diodes and applications

content.title: PN Junction Diode
content.description: A PN junction is formed when P-type and N-type semiconductor materials are joined together. This creates a depletion region with unique electrical properties essential for modern electronics.
keyPoints: P-type material has holes as majority carriers
N-type material has electrons as majority carriers
Depletion region forms at the junction
Built-in potential barrier prevents current flow
Forward bias reduces barrier, reverse bias increases it
applications: Rectifier circuits for AC to DC conversion

content.title: Zener Diode
content.description: Zener diodes are specially designed to operate in reverse breakdown region, providing precise voltage regulation. They maintain constant voltage across their terminals when reverse biased beyond the zener voltage.
keyPoints: Two breakdown mechanisms: Zener and Avalanche
Low dynamic resistance in breakdown region
Temperature coefficient varies with Zener voltage

content.title: LED & Photodiode
content.description: Light Emitting Diodes (LEDs) convert electrical energy to light, while photodiodes convert light to electrical energy. Both are crucial components in optoelectronic applications.
keyPoints: LEDs emit light when forward biased

content.title: BJT Fundamentals
content.description: Bipolar Junction Transistors consist of three layers of semiconductor material forming two PN junctions. They can amplify current and act as switches, making them fundamental building blocks of electronic circuits.
keyPoints: Three regions: Emitter, Base, and Collector
Two types: NPN and PNP transistors
Two PN junctions: Base-Emitter and Base-Collector
Three operating regions: Active, Cutoff, Saturation

content.title: Field Effect Transistors
content.description: Field Effect Transistors control current flow using an electric field. They offer high input impedance and are voltage-controlled devices, unlike current-controlled BJTs.
keyPoints: Two main types: JFET and MOSFET
Channel can be N-channel or P-channel

content.title: Transistor Amplifiers
content.description: Transistor amplifiers increase the amplitude of input signals. Different configurations offer varying characteristics in terms of gain, input/output impedance, and frequency response.
keyPoints: Three basic configurations: CE, CB, CC
Common Emitter: High voltage and current gain
Common Collector: High input impedance, unity gain

opamps.title: Operational Amplifiers
objectives: Understand ideal and practical op-amp characteristics
Analyze linear and non-linear op-amp circuits

content.title: Operational Amplifier Fundamentals
content.description: Operational amplifiers are high-gain differential amplifiers with very high input impedance and low output impedance. They form the backbone of analog signal processing circuits.
keyPoints: Two golden rules for ideal op-amp analysis

content.title: Linear Op-Amp Applications
content.description: In linear applications, op-amps operate with negative feedback, providing stable and predictable gain characteristics. These circuits form the foundation of analog signal processing.

content.title: Non-Linear Op-Amp Applications
content.description: Non-linear op-amp circuits operate without negative feedback or with positive feedback, creating switching and timing circuits. These applications exploit the high gain characteristics of op-amps.
keyPoints: Hysteresis can be added with positive feedback
Used in digital and timing applications
